docs.title: ApneaScrap
docs.text: ApneaScrap experiments with DIY freediving gear and shares findings with the community.

docs.title: Research Notes: DIY Carbon Bifin BOM
docs.text:
Now that I’ve mapped out the foot pockets, I want to gather everything I need for actually building a short carbon bifin blade. This is basically my BOM (bill of materials) plus a few notes on layering and finishing.

The problems I need to solve here are: 1. Which carbon fabrics and resin to use 2. How to prepare and laminate properly 3. What to use as a support base 4. How many layers are typical for bifins 5. How to finish the blades with rails and glue

docs.title: Core Materials
docs.text:
Carbon cloths (from Easy Composites): - 210 g 3k plain weave - 200 g 3k plain weave (same as above) - 200 g 3k green twill — decorative option - 650 g 12k twill — heavy, budget-friendly stiffness - 450 g 12k twill - 300 g 3k biaxial ±45° — for torsional strength

Carbon ribbons: - 80 g spread-tow ribbon, 15 mm — useful for reinforcement strips along rails or centerline.

Epoxy resin: - EL2 Epoxy Laminating Resin

docs.title: Prep and Vacuum
docs.text:
• Easylease chemical release agent or Mould Release Wax
  • Peel Ply
  • Breather Fabric
  • Vacuum Bagging Film — useful video: VB160 tutorial

docs.title: Support Base
docs.text:
I’ll need a flat sheet to laminate against:

  • Polycarbonate glazing sheet
  • Wickes Durable Clear Acrylic Sheet
  • Toolstation polycarbonate sheet

I still need to test which one works best. Acrylic scratches, polycarbonate might flex, but both should be fine for smaller training fins.

docs.title: Layering and Sizes
docs.text:
From the references I found:

  • Leaderfins → 7–8 layers, blade size ~24 cm × 54 cm
  • C4 → 7 layers, but much longer (around 90 cm)
  • DIY YouTube builds → around 6 layers

For a short training bifin, I’m probably aiming at 6–7 layers, depending on stiffness.

Reference image: Leaderfins carbon stereofins

docs.title: Finishing
docs.text:
Rails: - Waterway fin rails kit - Rail glues mentioned: Loctite 480 or 3M Marine 5200 - Good reading on rails: Spearfishing World thread

The rails help channel water and also protect the blade edge.

docs.title: References I Don’t Want to Lose
docs.text:
• Easy Composites Laminating Starter Kit
  • Easy Composites vacuum bagging film tutorial
  • Leaderfins carbon stereofins photo

docs.title: Where I’m At
docs.text:
For a short carbon training bifin, I’ll probably go with: - ~6–7 layers of 200 g 3k fabric, maybe mixing in a heavier layer (450–650 g) for stiffness - EL2 epoxy resin - Laminating on an acrylic/polycarbonate sheet - Adding rails with Loctite 480 after trimming

This should give me a small, stiff blade that can take some abuse during training without overcomplicating the build.

docs.title: Research Notes: DIY Carbon Monofin BOM
docs.text:
After mapping out bifins, I want to gather materials and design notes for building a monofin blade. This will be a bit more complex than bifins because monofins need more lateral stability and usually use internal reinforcements.

The problems I need to solve are: 1. Which materials carry over from the bifin build 2. What extra elements a monofin blade needs (ribs, edge trims, reinforcements) 3. Typical dimensions of monofins 4. How many layers are used in commercial examples 5. How to finish the blade for durability

docs.title: Core Materials
docs.text:
Most of the BOM is the same as the bifins:

  • Carbon cloths (200–650 g, plain weave, twill, biaxial)
  • Carbon ribbons (spread-tow strips for reinforcement)
  • EL2 epoxy laminating resin
  • Release agent / mould wax
  • Peel ply + breather + vacuum bagging film

docs.title: Monofin-Specific Materials
docs.text:
• Rubber U-channel trim — protects blade edges from chipping
  • Neoprene strips / rubber — add lateral stiffness and stabilize the blade
  • High-density neoprene sheet — used in some designs for damping and structural support

These help with lateral stability, which is critical in a wide monofin blade.

docs.title: Sizes and Dimensions
docs.text:
Some references from commercial monofins:

  • Molchanovs PRO Monofin 4 (Regular): 72–74 cm length × 70 cm width
  • Molchanovs PRO Monofin 4 (Small): 70–72 cm length × 68 cm width
  • Cetma Taras Monofin: max width ~69 cm

So the range seems to be 70–74 cm wide, 68–74 cm long.

Reference article: Apneapassion on Cetma Taras dimensions

docs.title: Layering
docs.text:
From examples I’ve seen:

  • 10+ layers is common for full carbon monofins
  • Many use internal carbon ribs for stiffness distribution

Visual references: - Oceaner monofin layering - Cetma Taras internal structure - Bluewater Freediving ribs example

docs.title: Internal and Side Reinforcements
docs.text:
Most high-end monofins use reinforcement structures:

  • Internal ribs: strips of carbon inside the laminate for stiffness
  • Strong side ribs: thicker rails or carbon laminates that act like wings, resisting side flex
  • Examples:
  • Waterway 6-rib system
  • Molchanovs monofin
  • Goldfin side ribs
  • Junko Kitahama competition fin

docs.title: Finishing
docs.text:
• Edge protection: rubber U-channel trim
  • Rails (optional, depending on how stable the blade feels)
  • Sanded and rounded blade edges for safety and durability

docs.title: References I Don’t Want to Lose
docs.text:
• DIY monofin forum thread
  • Cetma Taras monofin breakdown
  • Oceaner carbon monofin layering
  • Bluewater Freediving internal ribs example

docs.title: Where I’m At
docs.text:
Compared to bifins, a DIY monofin clearly needs: - More layers (10+) for stiffness - Internal ribs to control flex and power transfer - Side reinforcements to prevent wobbling - Rubber edge trim for protection

The challenge will be building internal ribs into the laminate. That’s probably the biggest difference compared to the simpler bifin build.

docs.title: Research Notes: Foot Pockets for a Short Carbon Training Fin
docs.text:
I'm starting a little project: building a short carbon bifin for training. Before I even think about layering carbon, I need to figure out which foot pockets to use. This post is basically me collecting info and links in one place so I can make a decision later.

The main problems I need to solve are: 1. Which pockets people actually use and why 2. Which ones fit DIY blades 3. How much the angle and rails matter 4. Where to find solid technical references

docs.title: Popular models
docs.text:
• C4 – lightweight pockets available in multiple stiffnesses
  • Pathos – 33° angle, minimal rubber for direct power transfer
  • CETMA S-WiNG – ultralight design without side rails
  • Leaderfins Classic – includes integrated rails
  • SEAC – known for comfort
  • Mares Razor and Omer Stingray – traditional rubber pockets found on many entry-level fins

docs.title: Blade compatibility
docs.text:
These pockets accept a wide range of blades:

  • Cetma Composites S-WiNG
  • Mares Razor
  • Pathos
  • Capt. Nemo
  • Sporasub
  • OMER Stingray
  • UltraFins

docs.title: Resources
docs.text:
• C4 guide to pockets and blades PDF
  • Leaderfins footpockets: https://www.freedivershop.com/leaderfins-footpockets
  • UltraFins footpockets: https://www.freedivershop.com/ultrafins-footpockets

docs.title: Research Notes: Monofin Foot Pockets
docs.text:
This is the second half of my research — this time looking at monofin foot pockets. Most DIY monofins seem to either use dedicated monofin pockets or just adapt bifin pockets. I want to collect the options here to see which direction makes sense for a DIY build.

The main problems I need to solve are: 1. What dedicated monofin pockets exist 2. How bifin pockets get adapted for monofins 3. Which options make sense for training vs. performance

docs.title: Dedicated Monofin Foot Pockets
docs.text:
A couple of manufacturers make pockets specifically for monofins:

  • Waterway Monofin Pockets Flat (not angled) design. Old-school style, simple and sturdy.

  • CETMA Modular Monofin Uses a modular system so blades can be swapped. Also not angled.

Both are purpose-built for monofins, but the lack of angle might make them feel stiffer and less ergonomic compared to Pathos-style bifin pockets.

docs.title: Adapted Bifin Pockets for Monofins
docs.text:
It turns out a lot of commercial monofins just adapt bifin foot pockets:

  • Waterway Nemo Wing Monofin – looks like standard bifin pockets mounted onto a monofin blade.
  • Oceaner Carbon Monofin – same idea, bifin-style pockets glued/attached to a wide blade.

This approach is appealing for DIY because bifin pockets are easier to source, and I can choose comfort/angle (Pathos, SEAC, Leaderfins, etc.) based on preference.

docs.title: Training Monofins
docs.text:
For pool work and technique training, there are monofins built specifically for fast tempo kicking:

  • Finis Evo Monofin – small blade, very quick response, designed for swimming drills.

Not a traditional freediving monofin, but worth noting as inspiration for a short, snappy training blade.

docs.title: References I Don’t Want to Lose
docs.text:
• Waterway monofin pockets
  • CETMA modular monofin system
  • Waterway Nemo Wing monofin
  • Oceaner Carbon Monofin
  • Finis Evo training monofin

docs.title: Where I’m At
docs.text:
Right now I see two directions:

  • Dedicated monofin pockets (Waterway, CETMA) → simple but not angled, less ergonomic.
  • Bifin pockets adapted to monofins (Waterway Nemo Wing, Oceaner) → more flexibility, and I can pick pockets I already like (Pathos, SEAC, Leaderfins).

For DIY, the adapted bifin pocket route looks way easier and gives me more control over comfort and angle. That might be the smarter first step before I experiment with dedicated monofin pockets.

docs.title: Techniques overview
docs.text:
Versioned recipes with Pool / Max labels. Pick a technique, compare versions, and start building.

  • Acrylic base
  • Buoyancy test
  • Carbon layup
  • Flex test rig
  • Glue fin rails
  • Surface finish
  • Vacuum gauge

docs.title: Acrylic base — compare versions
docs.text: Version Use Status Maturity Cost Tooling Time Pros Tradeoffs v2 acrylic + wedges Pool Active Stable Low Low Short Light, cheap, fast Can bow if over-clamped v1 wood support Pool Active Stable Medium Low Medium Very stiff Heavy, bulky

docs.title: Acrylic base v1 — wood support
docs.text: 25° wooden base with acrylic sheets for laminating carbon fin blades.

docs.title: Problem
docs.text: Laminating carbon fin blades requires a surface that matches blade geometry. The blade has a flat footpocket connection and an angled active area (about 20–30°). A flat surface can't reproduce this transition.

docs.title: Solution
docs.text:
An acrylic laminating surface sits on a wooden angled base.

  • Base construction: side supports cut at 25° and fixed with metal brackets for a rigid incline.
  • Laminating surface: acrylic sheets taped down with double-sided tape, creating a smooth, replaceable platform.

docs.title: Materials
docs.text:
• Wooden board (base)
  • Wooden side supports cut at 25°
  • Metal brackets with screws
  • Acrylic sheets sized to the vacuum bag
  • Double-sided tape

docs.title: Tools
docs.text:
• Saw
  • Drill and screwdriver
  • Measuring tools (square, protractor, tape measure)
  • Sandpaper

docs.title: Time Required
docs.text:
• Cutting and assembling wooden support: 1–2 hours
  • Preparing and mounting acrylic sheet: 15–30 minutes
  • Total build time: 1.5–2.5 hours

docs.title: Trade-offs
docs.text:
• Wooden support adds cutting, fitting, and bracket installation.
  • Entire base must fit inside the vacuum bag.
  • Gap between angled section and support can trap air and bend the acrylic during bagging.

docs.title: Acrylic Base with Wedge Supports
docs.text: This document describes how to build a modular acrylic base with wedge supports for laminating carbon fins. The example shown is for a 70 × 70 cm monofin, but the same technique can be adapted for bifins or other blade sizes.

docs.title: Base Dimensions
docs.text:
• Target working area (monofin example): ~80 × 90 cm
  • Purpose: Provides enough surface for a 70 × 70 cm monofin blade plus sealing margin
  • Support requirement: Must be placed on a flat, rigid surface such as a table or workbench
  • Protection: Place a plastic sheet under the base to protect the table surface

docs.title: Materials
docs.text:
• 6 × A3 acrylic sheets (2 mm thick)
  • 4 sheets for the flat blade section (2 wide × 2 tall)
  • 2 sheets for the angled footpocket section
  • Electrical tape for sealing the joints
  • Plastic stackable wedges to create the angled section under the footpockets
  • Protective plastic sheet (to cover the table surface beneath the acrylic)

docs.title: Tools
docs.text:
• Isopropyl alcohol and cloth (for cleaning sheet edges)
  • Scissors or knife (for trimming electrical tape)
  • Measuring tape or ruler (for alignment)
  • Squeegee, roller, or thumb pressure (for pressing tape flush)

docs.title: Time Required
docs.text:
• Base assembly: ~30 minutes
  • Wedge placement & alignment: ~10 minutes

docs.title: Assembly (Monofin Example)
docs.text:
1. Prepare the surface
  2. Place a plastic sheet on a flat, rigid table or bench.

  3. Ensure there is no dust or debris under the plastic.

  4. Arrange acrylic sheets

  5. Flat blade section: 4 A3 sheets in a 2 × 2 layout (~59 × 84 cm).

  6. Footpocket section: 2 A3 sheets side by side (~29.7 × 84 cm).

  7. Join sheets

  8. Clean edges with isopropyl alcohol.
  9. Bridge each joint with electrical tape, overlapping slightly (1–2 mm).

  10. Press tape firmly to remove trapped air and keep surface flush.

  11. Add wedge supports

  12. Place plastic stackable wedges under the footpocket section.
  13. Adjust wedge height to set the required angle (typically 20–30° for a monofin).
  14. Ensure wedges are stable and evenly distributed.

docs.title: Tradeoffs
docs.text:
• Advantage: This version does not require a heavy wooden support structure, making it much easier and faster to put together.
  • Advantage: Modular design — acrylic sheets and wedges can be stored flat and reused for different versions.
  • Drawback: The base cannot be placed as a whole into a vacuum bag.
  • Drawback: The only viable vacuum method is sealing the edges of the bag around the acrylic surface, which is less flexible than a solid one-piece base.

docs.title: Adaptation for Bifins
docs.text:
• Use the same base principle: flat section + small angled section for the footpockets.
  • Fewer acrylic sheets are needed since bifin blades are narrower.
  • For bifins around 20–22 cm wide per blade, two A3 sheets side by side are often enough for the flat section.

docs.title: Flex test rig — compare versions
docs.text: Version Use Status Maturity Cost Tooling Time Pros Tradeoffs v1 weight belt test Shop Active Draft Low Low Short Quick to set up Less precise

docs.title: Flex test rig v1: weight belt test
docs.text: Goal Measure how much load makes the tip vertical (90°) and where the blade bends (root, mid, tip).

docs.title: Setup
docs.text:
• Clamp: Fix the blade root flat with ≈80 mm clamped depth. Use rubber pads to protect and prevent slip.
  • Span: Measure blade length L from clamp line to tip.
  • Marks: Put dots on one edge at:
  • Root zone ≈ 0.3 L
  • Mid zone ≈ 0.6 L
  • Tip zone ≈ 0.9 L
  • Weight belt loading:
  • Wrap a weight belt snugly around the blade.
  • Place dive weights on top of the blade at the tip (L) and mid zone (0.6 L).
  • Keep a 2:1 ratio — twice as much load at the tip as at the mid.
  • Ensure weights are centered so they press straight down, not on the rails.
  • Camera: Place a phone side-on, level with blade mid-height.
  • Reference: Tape a ruler or printed grid behind the blade.

docs.title: Step 1 — Load until tip is vertical
docs.text:
1. Add weights to tip and mid (2:1 ratio).
  2. After each step, check the tip angle with an angle finder or from the side photo.
  3. Stop when the last 20 mm of the tip points straight down (≈90°).
  4. Record total weight used (belt + dive weights).

Formula:

F90 = m × 9.81 (N)

docs.title: Step 2 — Measure bend at 3 zones
docs.text:
• Take a side photo at that load.
  • From the grid/photo, estimate local slope (angle) at each zone:
  • θ_root at 0.3 L
  • θ_mid at 0.6 L
  • θ_tip at 0.9 L

docs.title: Data to record
docs.text:
• Clamp depth (mm)
  • Blade span L (mm)
  • Load method: belt with weights on top (tip + mid, 2:1 ratio)
  • F90 (N)
  • θ_root, θ_mid, θ_tip (degrees at F90)

docs.title: Flex test rig v1: basic rig
docs.text: Span 500 mm; loads 10 kg and 15 kg; dial indicator at tip. Record deflection for comparison.

docs.title: Surface finish — compare versions

docs.title: Vacuum gauge — compare versions
docs.text: Version Use Status Maturity Cost Tooling Time Pros Tradeoffs v1 syringe gauge Bagging Active Stable Low Low Short Cheap, sealed, clear plunger movement Only reads mild vacuum (~−20 kPa)

docs.title: Vacuum gauge v1 — syringe gauge
docs.text: A simple gauge to monitor mild vacuum (~81 kPa absolute, −20 kPa gauge) directly inside a vacuum bag. It uses Boyle’s law: trapped air expands as pressure drops, moving a rubber plunger seal you can read through the bag.

docs.title: Parts
docs.text:
• 1 × syringe (10 mL or 20 mL, ideally thin barrel for more travel)
  • Luer-lock or push-on tip cap (to seal airtight)
  • Candle wax (for plunger lubrication)
  • Breather fabric (to wrap gauge and protect from resin)
  • Permanent marker (to mark calibration lines)

docs.title: Build Steps
docs.text:
1. Modify plunger
  2. Remove plunger from syringe.

  3. Cut off the plastic rod, leaving only the rubber seal.

  4. Prepare barrel

  5. Clean inside of syringe.

  6. Lightly rub candle wax on the rubber seal for low friction.

  7. Seal the syringe

  8. Insert rubber seal back into barrel at the start volume:
    • 5 mL mark for a 10 mL syringe
    • 10 mL mark for a 20 mL syringe

  9. Cap the tip airtight with a Luer-lock or push-on tip cap.

  10. Mark the scale

  11. Draw an ambient mark at the initial plunger position.

  12. Mark your target 80% atmospheric (~81 kPa abs):

    • 10 mL syringe → +1.25 mL (plunger moves ~7.6 mm on standard barrel, ~20 mm on thin insulin barrel)
    • 20 mL syringe → +2.5 mL (plunger moves ~8.9 mm)

  13. Wrap and place

  14. Wrap syringe loosely in breather fabric so resin cannot touch it.
  15. Place it on top of breather stack, markings facing upward for reading through film.

docs.title: Calibration Reference
docs.text:
Target positions relative to start volume:

Absolute Pressure % of Atmosphere 10 mL Syringe (start 5 mL) 20 mL Syringe (start 10 mL) 101 kPa 100% (ambient) 5.0 mL 10.0 mL 95 kPa 94% 5.33 mL (Δ0.33) 10.67 mL (Δ0.67) 90 kPa 89% 5.63 mL (Δ0.63) 11.26 mL (Δ1.26) 85 kPa 84% 5.96 mL (Δ0.96) 11.92 mL (Δ1.92) 81 kPa 80% target 6.25 mL (Δ1.25) 12.5 mL (Δ2.5) 75 kPa 74% 6.75 mL (Δ1.75) 13.5 mL (Δ3.5)

Δ = plunger movement from ambient

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
• Thin syringes = more visible plunger travel. An insulin-style syringe can give ~2–3× more movement than a standard barrel.
  • Always mark ambient before sealing.
  • Wrap well in breather; the plunger must not be glued by resin.
  • Works best for mild vacuum (~−20 kPa gauge).

docs.title: Advantages
docs.text:
• Ultra-cheap (under $1 in parts)
  • No electronics, no second syringe needed
  • Fully sealed, safe to place inside bag
  • Large visible plunger movement with thin syringes
  • Perfect for confirming steady ~80% atmospheric pressure during cure
